item.title: Making a visionboard in Sketch
item.description:
Firstly, thank you to everyone who‚Äôs reached out to me in the past 24 hours. I never expected such overwhelming support. To those of you who have experienced very similar things, I hope it helps to know you‚Äôre not alone - it‚Äôs the whole reason I decided to publish yesterday‚Äôs post.

The second most common thing I heard was: ‚ÄúThat visionboard is really neat! How do I make one?‚Äù So I made a screencast to show you how.

How to make a grid of cool images in Sketch

I actually already made my 2016 board a few days ago, so it was easy for me to film the process. The screencast will walk you through all the steps. You‚Äôll get a sneak peak of my next post: my goals for next year! üòâ

Essentially you need a bunch of images that you‚Äôd like to use and you think represent whichever goals you have. I often use Pinterest, but have also been known to dip into Unsplash.

You can also create your own from your own photography or from combining your favourite quotes and typography using a host of different apps: Over, Post, and more.

I then used Sketch to make it into the full image you‚Äôll see featured on the blog shortly. Essentially I calculate the size of each image, and then create rectangles for each. These will mask the images, once I start incorporating those. Easy! :)

Setting goals

I am a big believer of setting goals and having constant reminders of them. I feel like New Years Resolutions have gotten a bad rep, but that is often because they don‚Äôt last very long. People take on too many things at the same time, and burn out from them just a few weeks in. No wonder they‚Äôre considered a joke. The practice of setting them, and improving on yourself isn‚Äôt though!

What I tend to do with these boards is put in a few daily rituals that I would like to shape, for instance meditating regularly. The visual representation reminds me of it throughout the year, so I don‚Äôt forget to try and do it as often as I can. Surely, it may not be every day, but at least I‚Äôm still working on it come June.

The second thing I urge you to consider are some goals you can easily tick off or where the result is obvious. For instance, getting a driver‚Äôs license or going to a specific country. Once you‚Äôve done that, you can see how you‚Äôre starting to make progress. It also means that you don‚Äôt have to focus on all of these right now. I have the reminder that at some point in the year I want to take driving lessons, but it doesn‚Äôt have to be January. It could be July.

It‚Äôs also why I like to put 23 goals down: they‚Äôre supposed to last the whole year and they‚Äôre supposed to be a bit of a stretch. I‚Äôd rather fail a few, but have completed most, than setting myself only 6, say.

Take from this what you will, but it‚Äôs worked for me for quite a while ‚ò∫Ô∏è.

If you end up making any, I‚Äôd love to see them. Let‚Äôs make 2016 an awesome year for self-improvement!

item.title: Goodbye 2015, Hello 2016
item.description:
I intended on writing a ‚Äúthoughts on the year‚Äù when I decided to blog again just a few weeks ago, but gosh, has a lot changed since then again. This is gonna be a long one - brace yourselves :).

2015

I‚Äôll start right off the bat and say that 2015 was not a great year. Don‚Äôt get me wrong, a lot of good things happened, but personally I‚Äôve just not felt that great and here‚Äôs a little bit on why.

The year started off pretty decent, as I (and the people I worked with I‚Äôm sure) had a much needed, long Christmas break. In 2014 we had a massive crunch time project, trying to ship SwiftKey for iOS, and I don‚Äôt think we managed to allow ourselves to take a breather until the end of the year. I went to the USA and hung out with my family. It was amazing.

I came back to work with renewed energy, but found myself loosing that energy very quickly. Many things around me were changing, and for some reason it got to me. Maybe it was work, maybe I was long overdue another episode, but I found myself getting more and more depressed again. So much so, that around April our wonderful head of HR told me to go home. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry about it, just focus on yourself. Just take some time.‚Äù

It‚Äôs a relief hearing this from your employer, when you try so hard to do the best you can at work and often feel like you can‚Äôt show any weakness. I took this week to think about what it is that I wanted to do. Maybe it was time for a shift in my day to day. Up until this point, I had been doing more design work, and had been asking for it also, but what if I could somehow formalise it more? Structure it better?

What that requires though, is an understanding and acceptance that someone can genuinely do both crafts to a certain standard. This is something that is, I think, still hard to swallow for many. And for me, at that point, I felt like I could no longer choose between engineering and design. If anything, I was leaning more and more to doing design full time because there was a point where I felt I lost any faith in myself being a decent engineer.

This was the first time I‚Äôve ever been depressed while in a work environment. It wasn‚Äôt high school, it wasn‚Äôt uni. I couldn‚Äôt give myself the break I needed and then make up for lost time by hitting exams hard. I couldn‚Äôt avoid people. Instead, I had to come into work every day and face stand-up. Never had I come to hate an agile practice more. How do you say ‚ÄúI felt absolute rubbish yesterday and barely managed to get out of bed let alone be productive. Oh and today isn‚Äôt much better‚Äù?

So started a completely new chapter of my life. Anxiety.

I felt like I had to continuously keep up appearances at work, so I over-promised on things, and worked myself into the ground trying to complete them despite feeling depressed. This meant there were no evenings anymore. No weekends anymore. Just continuous guilt over trying to finish something that should be a simple task. And the more this happened, the more I started believing that clearly it was me - I was no longer capable of writing code.

Somewhere in this cycle of avoidance, pressure, and sadness, my body gave up. I had been feeling chest pains for a long while already, but I didn‚Äôt know I was genuinely experiencing anxiety symptoms. At some point in June, I had a panic attack.

For those of you who don‚Äôt know what panic attacks are, they are in all honesty pretty harmless. But they are terrifying when you‚Äôre in them. You feel like you‚Äôve lost all control over your body. Your body goes into full fright or flight mode, and I found myself shaking, crying, and hyper ventilating for well over an hour. You‚Äôre not dying and you know it, but you feel like you do.

My boyfriend tried to keep me calm over the phone while a good friend rushed over to my place to take me to A&E (on recommendation of my GP). After what, retrospectively, turned out to be a pretty hilarious few hours in hospital (we ordered Deliveroo!), I was literally given a chill pill and told that I should really take a break from work. Not only that, this was something I now needed to ‚Äúmanage‚Äù.

I felt pretty broken. Anything and everything started affecting me. As I have quoted to many already, it got to a point that Tesco could‚Äôve run out of spinach and tears would start welling up in my eyes. I just could no longer handle the world.

I decided I needed a change. A lot had changed at work, and it no longer seemed like the right fit. I was offered another job that I was quite excited about and I decided to take the leap. Making these changes (and more) felt great, because I felt like I was in control again.

Now comes the part that‚Äôs probably the hardest for me to talk about. I ignored my instincts and it got me into a pretty shitty situation. The new job didn‚Äôt feel right, not from day one. I had read Ash‚Äôs post and remember how he once quit upon starting. I desperately wanted to, but because everything that had happened this year I declared that it must‚Äôve been me. I ignored how I felt, and pushed forward.

I started on a new codebase, a new challenge, and it was amazing. I found such joy in development again and if there‚Äôs one thing I take away from this it‚Äôs that. And I am immensely grateful for it. Turns out I‚Äôm actually a pretty decent engineer, at least, more so than I thought of myself 4 months prior. Faith in myself returned and I was doing great again.

What I couldn‚Äôt get on board with is just about everything else. The way things were done and run were just not what I had imagined, nor what I was told to expect. I figured that a lot of it was because it was a small and young place. Friends of mine had faced the challenge of being in a startup, surely this couldn‚Äôt be any different. I spoke up. I tried to stand up for what I believed in and affect positive change. But it seemed as if the more I did that, the more things went in the opposite direction.

Just two months in, I decided to quit. I felt like I was giving up, but after everything this year, I felt that I could no longer work in a place where the culture was so out of touch with how I saw things. It just wasn‚Äôt worth the dread of going into work. There were other places I could contribute to in a much healthier way.

Never, ever, did I expect to face the backlash I did when I announced my resignation (whilst still on probation period - that‚Äôs what they‚Äôre for right?). I was aware that this would not be great for them and I wanted to work together on a good outcome. But they made things personal, and that was just a blow below the belt.

I had come quite far in getting better. My therapist, who makes me fill out some point based survey every time I see her, said that before this I was essentially considered ‚Äúrecovered‚Äù. After this I scored the worst I had until date. Eventually I had a panic attack on the tube. I somehow managed to get above ground, find a corner on a street, and break down until my boyfriend came running to find me and take me home. He has been amazing in all of this. This was the second time I had a panic attack, and hopefully the last.

My GP suggested medication and I, after giving it quite some thought, refused. Earlier this year it was me. I was feeling terrible and I was putting myself through unnecessary anxiety. It could‚Äôve made sense then. This time around, it was not me. It was circumstantial and I trust myself to never ever put myself in this kind of situation again. I can‚Äôt tell you how proud I am that I had the guts to quit.

Which leads me to the good of 2015, because I promise you, there is quite a lot of that too! The above may have been the dominating theme, but actually, a whole host of things were absolutely awesome. A lot of that is thanks to the fact that I reminded myself of it every day: I had a small ‚Äúvisionboard‚Äù on my phone‚Äôs lock screen. Let‚Äôs take a look at what I did managed to achieve.

I assembled visual representations of various personal goals I had for this year (Pinterest was a useful source of imagery), to remind me long after most new year‚Äôs resolutions have been forgotten. I purposefully didn‚Äôt make them massively centered around work. I wanted them to be about random things I was interested in.

From left to right, top to bottom:

  1. Go lie on a beach
  2. Go to WWDC
  3. Go to Paris with my mum
  4. Make the most out of sunny days
  5. Master the pidgeon pose in yoga
  6. Get into drinking my green juices again (or ‚ÄúSwamp Juice‚Äù as my fellow SwiftKeyers would call it)
  7. Practice gratitude
  8. Envision and going after what I want
  9. Designing and shipping a native icon library
  10. Being less afraid
  11. Choosing to respond with kindness
  12. Put effort into what I wear
  13. Go to Berlin again
  14. -
  15. Make a panting
  16. Get back into photography
  17. See at least one friend from a different continent that I hadn‚Äôt in a while
  18. Work more on illustrations
  19. Shut up and listen more
  20. Do a 5k run
  21. Be more spontaneous
  22. Go somewhere alone
  23. Get back into cooking
  24. Putting effort into what I want to get better at

Go lie on a beach ‚úÖüòç

I went to Dubai to visit a friend and we went to the beach! It was sooo relaxing. I ended up going by myself a few times too.

Go to WWDC ‚úÖüòÜ

I was hoping to simply partake in the lottery and otherwise go anyway. There is usually so much going on in SF that time of year, that it‚Äôs well worth just hanging out. This year however, Apple opened up their scholarship to women also. I spent a pretty solid 36 hours writing the submission app and was awarded a free ticket to WWDC. Say what?! Definitely one of the highlights of the year, not to mention I got to meet this guy and listen to The Weeknd live (Honza had to keep me from bouncing off my chair).

Go to Paris with my mum ‚ùåüòî

Unfortunately this didn‚Äôt work out, as I was travelling so much this year already. Quite gutted, but we‚Äôre trying to work things out for next year.

Make the most out of sunny days ‚úÖüòä

Due to all the ‚Äúnot wanting to leave the house‚Äù, I feel like I didn‚Äôt make use of the summer as much as I would‚Äôve otherwise, but I still spent a good deal outdoors and on our patio. I love the feel of sun on my skin, and I think that I did experience that a decent amount this year.

Master the pidgeon pose in yoga ‚ùåüò†üò≠

You know that feeling when you roll out your mat, you stare at it, you do one or two poses and you just end up in child‚Äôs pose not wanting to do anything else? That has been me all year. 2014 was a fantastic yoga year, 2015 was not. I am making it a top priority for 2016.

Get into drinking my green juices again ‚úÖüëå

I did this a lot. It‚Äôs still not every single day (keeping the supply of spinach incoming isn‚Äôt always easy), but a lot of what I have consumed this year has been in the form of green coloured juices and smoothies. Nom!

Practice gratitude ‚úÖ‚ò∫Ô∏è

I contribute my overall ‚Äúbeing cheery‚Äù to this and I believe it‚Äôs what kept me going this year. A lot of things have been wonderful and I am immensely thankful for it. I think it‚Äôs quite telling when, whilst being depressed, almost everyone on my SwiftKey leaving card wrote that my positive energy and attitude is what will be missed.

Envision and going after what I want ‚úÖüôÇ

As much as I was filled with doubt, I think I managed to have the sense to look at what needed changing and taking the leap(s).

Designing and shipping a native icon library ‚ùå‚ùìüòØ

A project I‚Äôve been wanting to work on for a long time. It means combining my love for code and design, as well as just making my first pod. I am trying to get the simplest version of it out before the end of the year.

Being less afraid ‚úÖüôÇ

Funnily enough, I think this worked out pretty well. My body has never felt this scared in my life, yet my mind is slowly becoming more and more resilient than ever.

Choosing to respond with kindness - ü§î

I‚Äôd like to think I‚Äôve done this. I have received quite some positive feedback, though I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôve managed to piss people off also. Some of these things are continuous journeys. I could be kinder to myself however, and in the last few months I have tried to make improvements there also.

Put effort into what I wear ‚úÖüòé

I cleared out my closet, leaving only choice pieces that all fit together properly. I don‚Äôt even need to think twice about getting dressed in the morning and feel good in just about everything I own. Absolute win, if you ask me.

Go to Berlin again ‚úÖüòä

Berlin holds a special place in my heart and it was great being there again. Even more so, because I was asked to speak at UIKonf! Whilst not my best talk (in my opinion), it seemed to definitely be one of my best received talks :). It talks a lot about the struggle of being stuck between design and development, and it hopes to point out something I feel strongly about in our industry: this idea that one aspect of making a product can be considered ‚Äúbetter‚Äù than others - something I fundamentally disagree with. I remember being a bit nervous about going out there and calling us developers a bunch of arrogant people. The audience was amazing however, and seemed to be fine with it!

2015.. ‚úÖüòÖ

I made it through the year I guess?

Make a panting ‚úÖüòÉ

I went to a live drawing class this year, and made a sketch (nswf) I was pretty happy with! In general, I‚Äôve gotten more into painting again. I‚Äôm still trying to dedicate more time to it, but it‚Äôs headed in the right direction.

Get back into photography ‚ùåüòï

Apart from this one picture I took this year that I‚Äôm pleased with, I basically didn‚Äôt pick up my DSLR at all. I‚Äôm now at a stage where I‚Äôm not sure whether to sell it, or give it another go.

See at least one friend from a different continent that I hadn‚Äôt in a while ‚úÖüíØüòÑ

I saw a friend in Dubai, another one in California, another in Berlin, another from Amsterdam, and one of my favourite people is visiting from Canada in a few days. This year has been great for seeing my besties from all around the world. I am so happy to have them in my life.

Work more on illustrations ‚úÖüôÇ

While I didn‚Äôt design and print an illustration to hang on a wall (as was my intention), I did get into creating more and more visual pieces. From checklists, to roadmaps, to icons, to scenery, to processes, it‚Äôs lowered the barrier of opening Sketch / Affinity Designer and just making what‚Äôs in my head.

Shut up and listen more ‚úÖ‚ùìüò∂

For anyone that knows me in real life, I talk. A lot. I‚Äôd like to think that I‚Äôm pretty interactive when I chat and also listen, but still. I talk a lot. Considering I have always been like this (my mum got me ‚ÄúLittle Miss Chatterbox‚Äù when I was four), I think I took a step in the right direction for improving it. I did try and listen more actively this year. The funny thing with that is, you start to realise how not a lot of people always make sense‚Ä¶ So in turn I‚Äôve been trying to be more concrete in what message I try to deliver to others and just get to the point more often. It‚Äôs a work in progress.

Do a 5k run ‚úÖüòÄ

What can I say. Did it. Not in the time I had originally set for myself, but then again, I didn‚Äôt train. That‚Äôs okay. I still turned up to the race and I ran. And it felt great.

Be more spontaneous ‚úÖ‚ò∫Ô∏è

That‚Äôs how I choose to interpret this quote at least. I did some really fun and wild things this year. I somehow felt like I did more of it the year before, but that‚Äôs okay. It led me to experience great times.

Go somewhere alone ‚úÖ‚ùìüòØ

This is the first year I didn‚Äôt manage to get in a full solo trip, but I did travel to Dubai to see my friend who was often working, so a good chunk of that trip was just me. I went to Italy on my own for Pragma, but then some of that was spent with awesome friends from around the world.

Get back into cooking ‚úÖüòâ

I‚Äôve made some pretty awesome things this year, the highlight of which has been my most recent ‚Äúbrownie cookies‚Äù. Yes, they are as amazing as they sound! I saw a lot of myself in Ash‚Äôs Pragma talk, where he describes the road to expertise. There are a lot of things that I‚Äôm decent at, I‚Äôm trying to get better at, and I just plain suck at. Cooking is one of those that I know I‚Äôm great at.

Putting effort into what I want to get better at ‚úÖüòä

I think if anything, this is something I continued striving for and something that I have been most proud of. I may have felt like there were times when I threw in the towel, but I don‚Äôt think I did. The easy route is to complain, and I think I consciously choose to instead try and improve what I could. Myself, my health, my career, my relationships, and so forth. I am lucky that my friends also describe me as someone who doesn‚Äôt give up. It‚Äôs reassuring to know I can count on myself.

Great things that weren‚Äôt on the board, but still happened:

  • Speaking at AltConf, iOSDevUK, BeyondConf and more
  • Hosting my first workshop
  • Moving in with my boyfriend
  • Hiking and sauna-ing in Switzerland with friends
  • Visiting Poland with the iOS team for random shits and giggles
  • Being back in Edinburgh
  • Be taken on a surprise birthday trip to my favourite spa
  • Attending two cocktail courses - I now know a lot about rum and gin
  • Practicing mindfulness and meditations regularly
  • Blogging again (even though I didn‚Äôt complete NaNoWriBlo)
  • Being on a podcast

I stand by the fact that, in many ways, I had an amazing year. I developed as a person. Shit happens, yet life goes on. I still have all my loved ones in my life, which at the end of the day is all that matters to me - they are irreplaceable. A huge shout out to them for supporting me along the way.

I have great plans for 2016, and a new board is in the making. I will however spare you any more text and post it separately. If you managed to read all the way till the end - thank you :).

Hope your year was lovely, and wishing you all the best for the next!

Happy holidays, Maxim

item.title: My first podcast
item.description:
Something very exciting happened a few weeks ago. I recorded my first podcast! I was interviewed by Amelia from Steer for their upcoming conference Beyond, as I‚Äôll be speaking on Usability Testing there.

It‚Äôs out now, and you can listen to it here.

Recording

Recording a podcast is quite an interesting and surreal experience. After having recorded it, I couldn‚Äôt remember what it was that I said at all. And even weirder was that I experienced this feeling of ‚Äústage fright‚Äù after having recorded it. I think because I knew I wouldn‚Äôt be able to change anything anymore, and other people would be listening to it? Very odd.

Either way, it‚Äôs all done. I‚Äôm actually quite happy with it! They edited out one or two gaps of silence and a side comment here or there, but in all honesty, the way you hear it was pretty much how it was recorded.

Shownotes

I wanted to add some additional show notes. For those of you that listened to it and are new to iOS, allow me to expand on some of the things I said.

Resources

There are many! Building for a device can be quite different to building for web, say. But the community is lovely, and has thankfully taken the time to document their knowledge, trials, and errors carefully.

Official:

  • Apple WWDC Videos - See these as ‚ÄúApple University‚Äù, where they take you though all the available API they create for developers and how to use and leverage them.
  • Official Swift Resources - All about helping you get started with Swift
  • Official Swift Docs - Tells you all about the language. Available on the iBooks store for free also.
  • Official Class Docs - The language is separate from the framework Apple provides to leverage what the OS has to offer. Always consult the docs on how to‚Äôs and best practices! Example of UIView (to display things) here.

Community:

  • Objc.io - Purposefully written content by industry experts on all major topics in iOS development. Excellent.
  • NSHipster - Interesting content. If you‚Äôre discovering quirks and oddities about iOS / Mac development, chances are you‚Äôll find a post about that exact issue here.
  • iOSDevWeekly - A weekly curated newsletter rounding up interesting blog articles on iOS development.
  • This week in Swift - Another great curated newsletter, focussing on Swift specifically.
  • NSLondon Videos - The London meetup I mentioned. It has been running for a long time and thus collected a great deal of community shared information, tips, and tricks ‚Äî all recorded.
  • Open Source Code - One of the best ways to learn is to see how others do.

Community

Find local meetups near you. Meetup is a fantastic resource for getting to know the local scene. Also, head to Twitter and you‚Äôll find plenty there.

Leveraging the community is one of the best things you can do, because you realise you‚Äôre not alone in your struggles. Developing code comes with its own set of quirks that takes some time to figure out and get used to. None of us worked it all out overnight!

It can also be a very inspiring experience. I remember my first WWDC, my first meetup, and it made a significant difference in how I continued to approach my work.

Go at your own pace

Don‚Äôt feel like you have to conquer everything in one go. I still don‚Äôt know every single API or ‚Äúdomain‚Äù. For example, I have a lot of experience with keyboards from my time at SwiftKey, but I‚Äôve not done much with the camera (whereas, likely, someone who works on Instagram has).

Like I mention in the podcast: it‚Äôs easy to feel like you should know everything and if you don‚Äôt, you should work on acquiring this knowledge day and night. Yes, curiosity is fantastic. Yes, studying the ins and outs of iOS development is good. But running on no sleep and experiencing stress on a daily basis isn‚Äôt. Take a deep breath. Do what works for you.

Thanks

Finally, a big thank you to those who‚Äôve already shared it, tweeted it, and so forth. It means a lot :).

item.title: Changing up the terminal
item.description:
I recently overhauled my terminal. I had a great setup when I was in university, because I relied on the command line a lot, but since doing iOS development I‚Äôve let it slide. All I used it for was git, and the (by now) broken zsh configuration I had seemed to do the job.

I‚Äôve been wanting to try the fish shell for ages, but it wasn‚Äôt until I saw it all come together in Daniel‚Äôs terminal that I finally set aside time to do so.

Setting up a hotkey

First things first, easy access.

I used to have a hotkey for a terminal window. That was the whole reason I used iTerm. Why did I even stop doing that?!

  1. Download and install iTerm2 if you‚Äôre not using it already
  2. Go to preferences (cmd+, as always), ‚Äúkeys‚Äù tab
  3. Click on ‚ÄúShow/hide iTerm with a system-wide hotkey‚Äù
  4. Decide on the key (I use alt+space)
  5. I would recommend getting a dedicated profile so you can dim the background appropriately
  6. Try it!
  7. Prettify to your liking under profiles

About the dimming - I like that you can still see bits of the background, hence I‚Äôve got a dedicated profile where I can set the opacity of the background colour. You could also make it your default profile and it will most likely be solid, depending on what you normally use.

Fish

Secondly, I felt there was more my shell should be doing for me.

Fish suggest things as you type! This reminds me of this product I used to work on, lol‚Ä¶

Seriously though, fish predicts commands based on what you‚Äôve typed previously, and you can autocomplete these with the right arrow (or left I suppose, if you‚Äôre computer is set to Right to Left? I never tried..).

Installing is easy if you have homebrew: brew install fish, done! Don‚Äôt worry if you don‚Äôt have brew (although I would recommend it), more installation info can be found here.

Customised themes

Lastly, I like a pretty shell.

Just like zsh (which I‚Äôve used the past 6 years), fish has an ‚Äúoh my‚Äù version which allows for easy theming. Check it out here.

Like I mentioned, I blatantly copied Daniel and choose the agnoster theme. Mainly because it has thick chunky bits of colour, and that made it very easy to read. I like it when the prompt is visually quite separate from the commands I will be typing.

Speaking of colour, you can download iTerm profiles / colour schemes from this awesome site. It makes life so much easier! I went for n0tch2k, because I like that muted effect that still has some bright pastel colours.

Then finally, you need a ‚Äúpowerline font‚Äù for Agnoster to work well, or else the arrows won‚Äôt show up as expected. If you don‚Äôt have those, it may be that your prompt looks a bit like this:

The fonts can be found here, and there is a nice bash script to install them all.

I opted for Hack, and had the non-ASCII font set to a bit larger so that the arrows would match the coloured block precisely. I did this for both the default profile and the hotkey window, by the way.

And there you have it. I know there‚Äôs plenty more customisation that you can do, and I might explore that in the future, but for now I‚Äôm glad that I have an easily accessible, smart, and pretty shell to work with.

item.title: ‚ÄúNaBloWriMo‚Äù
item.description:
NaNoWriMo - Blog edition

I‚Äôve keenly followed NaNoWriMo (National Novel Writing Month) since I was fourteen or so, but never participated. I didn‚Äôt have ideas for a novel, I was too busy, something unexpected came up, you name it.

This year, I decided to change it up a bit. Instead of worrying about a novel, I‚Äôd tackle another writing project I‚Äôve been wanting to get around to for years. My blog.

Having had an on-and-off blog for as long as I can remember, it‚Äôs been too long without one. I briefly dabbled in a new wordpress one earlier this year (with too many unreleased posts), until Honza convinced me that something light and simple like Wintersmith was really the way forward.

It wasn‚Äôt just about the tools though. What I realised put me off blogging for so long is that whenever I read something back, it just didn‚Äôt seem right. You know that feeling when you hear yourself back on a recording? And your voice just sounds off? That‚Äôs what I have every. single. time.

So, welcome November 2015. The month where I, hopefully, find my writing voice.

NaBloWriMo - The Rules

NaNoWriMo has a simple definition: one month, 50,000 words. Oh, and it should be fiction.
